postcontent:
If you've always wanted to own an American classic pumpgun--and a Winchester at that--here's your chance.

And since I've dropped the price to $275, this is a rare opportunity to do so without busting the bank. Try finding ANY American-made pumpgun with real walnut stocks, polished and blued steel throughout, and no plastic internal parts for anywhere near $275.

This Model 12 is a field grade 12 gauge with a 2.75-inch chamber and 28-inch modified barrel. Serial number dates it to 1959, the pinnacle of Winchester's production in New Haven for the Model 12. Everyone knows what happened to Winchester quality after 1964, and this gun stands as a testimonial to the last of their great guns from the good old days. Sadly, they don't make them like this anymore.

Please see my photos below. I'd be happy to send additional photos, too, if you specify exactly what you'd like to see.

All numbers match on the gun, it is 100% original, with no modifications or alterations, and it cycles and shoots fine. The action racks straight and smoothly, with no binding or play, although it could probably benefit from a  thorough breakdown and cleaning. The wood is tight, straight-grained black walnut and is free of any cracks or substantial wear and shows only a few minor scratches and dings from field use and some loss of finish on the grip and near the black plastic Winchester buttplate. 

The bluing is in good shape throughout the gun, except for the left side of the receiver and the left breech end of the barrel, which have a few areas of shallow pitting where some surface rust was removed--and a good bit of the bluing--on the left side of the receiver. Likewise, there is a narrow line of shallow pitting on the left side of the chamber and extending up about 8 inches into the barrel. I suspect the gun may have been put up at one time on its left side while it was still damp, and moisture caused the rust on both these left-side exterior and interior surfaces.

But these are purely cosmetic flaws. This is still a perfectly functioning Model 12, ready for any use you have for it. Given its blems, it would be a great Model 12 to shoot when you don’t want to worry about exposing a prettier gun to rough conditions or weather. It cycles perfectly and has that unmistakable heft and balance that made the Model 12 THE legendary American pumpgun. If you've ever shouldered and swung a Model 12, you know exactly what I mean.

This gun would make an excellent pheasant gun or even a good duck gun for jump shooting or hunting close over decoys. It would also be a good candidate to have its barrel cut down and serve as a home defense gun. The Model 12 got its start as the original trench gun in WW I, and this one could certainly fill that role again with the right barrel length. Or, of course, with a honing of the barrel and a rebluing, it could be restored to factory-original condition. Or you could even swap out the barrel completely, as vintage Model 12 barrels with mirror bores are plentiful and cheap on Ebay. 

But I’ll leave that choice up to the new owner.
